awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Uncovering the Dynamics and Functionality of Origami Structures and Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Origami is the ancient art of folding paper into decorative shapes and geometries.  Over the last several decades, it evolved and became a design framework for many engineering and architecture applications.  Examples include deployable space structures, kinetic buildings, self-folding robots, surgery devices, and advanced materials.  Origami folding so far has been considered as a static process.  People typically focus on its design and geometry, or internal actuation mechanisms that makes the folding autonomous.  This award supports a collaborative project that will investigate the fundamental dynamic characteristics of origami folding.  In particular, the research will explore how to harness the extraordinary properties of origami for applications like vibration isolation at low frequency, recoverable impact absorption, and impulsive actuation.  Furthermore, the research will produce design tools that can generate sophisticated folding patterns and assign material properties that are suitable for a wide variety of dynamic performance requirements.  The results of this project will become the building blocks for the next generation of air, marine, and land vehicles, intelligent machines and robots, or smart infrastructures, enhancing their functionality, safety and sustainability. The findings will thus advance the aerospace, civil, mechanical, robotics and many other industries. Education and broadening participation plans will focus on student learning and community outreach at various levels and on the enhancement diversity through inclusion in the research activities of members of underrepresented minorities in science and engineering.

This research will, for the first time, rigorously investigate the dynamic characteristics of origami folding and develop its corresponding engineering potentials.  Preliminary studies have discovered that origami with generic crease patterns exhibits many attractive properties via folding, such as zero/negative stiffness, pressure dependent multi-stability, and piece-wise stiffness jump.  Such surprisingly rich properties and the corresponding dynamic responses will be analyzed in detail based on an equivalent truss-frame model, which transforms the continuous origami structure into a finite degree of freedom system.  The truss frame model would also become the basis of a comprehensive synthesis tool that incorporates crease perturbation and optimization, so that the origami can be customized for prescribed dynamic performances.  This synthesis tool will bridge the currently separated branches of studies: the mathematical theories of origami design/folding and the engineering of origami based applications.  Overall, the new modeling, analysis and synthesis tools for origami dynamics will create a significant intellectual leap and build a strong foundation for many future related research and development efforts.

Project Outcomes Report

Title: Collaborative Research - Uncovering the Dynamics and Functionality of Origami Structures and Materials

PI: Noel Perkins

Awardee: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

Award Number: 1634545

Award Ends: 08/31/2020

Introduction

Origami is an ancient art of folding paper into decorative shapes and geometries.  Over the last several decades, it evolved and became a design framework for many engineering applications.  Examples include deployable space structures, kinetic buildings, self-folding robots, surgery devices, and advanced materials.  Origami folding has mostly been considered as a static process in the past.  People typically focus on its design and geometry, or internal actuation mechanisms for folding.  This reward supports a collaborative research that investigated the fundamental dynamic characteristics of origami folding.  This research discovered the extraordinary dynamic properties of origami, which can be harnessed for high-performance engineering applications such as vibration isolation, impact absorption, wave controls, fast and smooth deployments, and impulsive actuation.  Furthermore, this research produced tools that can select geometric and material properties suitable for a wide variety of dynamic performance requirements. 

Intellectual merit

This research, for the first time, rigorously investigated the various dynamic characteristics of origami structures and developed their corresponding engineering potentials.  Studies have discovered that origami with generic crease patterns exhibits many attractive properties via folding.  Such surprisingly rich properties and the corresponding dynamic responses are analyzed in detail based on a reduced-order model, which transforms the continuous origami structure into a finite degree of freedom system.  The model also became the basis of a comprehensive tool that the origami can be customized for prescribed dynamic performances.  This research bridged the currently separated branches of studies: the mathematical theories of origami design/folding and the engineering of origami, especially in terms of the origamis' system dynamics characteristics in multistability, nonlinear vibration, self-locking, wave propagation, shape morphing, and deployment.  Overall, the proposed new modelling and analysis tools for origami dynamics created a significant intellectual leap and built a strong foundation for many future related research and development efforts. 

Broader Impact

Origami structures have applications in many engineering fields. An improved understanding of the fundamental processes governing origami dynamics is critical to systems in which such structures are employed. The results become the building blocks that will benefit the next generation of air, marine, and land vehicles, intelligent machines and robots, or smart infrastructures, enhancing their functionality, safety and sustainability. They will thus advance the aerospace, civil, mechanical, robotics and many other industries.

Summary & Conclusions

During the course of this research, we have worked on six major activities, investigating the dynamic characteristics of origami folding and examining their corresponding functionalities. A summary of the contributions is provided below.

A.  We performed a comprehensive study on the dynamics of origami folding through investigating a stacked Miura-Ori (SMO) structure with intrinsic bistability. The results of this research offer a wealth of fundamental insights into the nonlinear dynamics of origami folding and provide a solid foundation for developing foldable and deployable structures and materials with embedded dynamic functionalities.

B. We explored the mechanics and dynamics of integrated 4-vertex origami structure and the self-locking induced mechanical properties. The results of this research provide new scientific knowledge and a systematic framework for the design, analysis, and utilization of self-locking origami structures for many potential engineering applications. These unique characteristics of self-locking origami present new paths for creating programmable mechanical metamaterials with in-situ controllable mechanical properties.

C. We proposed a novel phononic structure based on origami architecture that can shift between different Bravais-lattice types for tunable wave propagation and waveguiding. The origami folding mechanism combined with the scalable nature of the origami architecture makes the origami phononic structure a novel and effective device for wave control applications across a range of frequencies.

D. Through an integration of origami folding with magnets, we investigated a novel approach to synthesize and harness multi-stable magneto-origami structures. The proposed magnet-based innovation effectively endows the origami structures with the long-desired tunability of the stability profile and mechanical properties, making them attractive in applications that call for adaptabilities, such as adjustable shape morphing and broadband energy harvesting.

E. We explored the deployment dynamics of Kresling structures with various system geometries and operating strategies. This research outcome suggested the strong potential of Kresling-based designs for deployable systems with robust and tunable performance.

F. The deployment dynamics of a non-rigid Miura origami sheet based on a bar-and-hinge approach with effective inertial is investigated. The findings of this research enable a deeper understanding of the transient dynamics of origami deployment and pave the way for new applications of origami-based deployable structures.
